Award.AbstractNarration:
Emission from gamma-ray burst (GRB) jets is complicated by the presence of free neutrons, magnetic fields, and random variability. This project is a systematic study of the jet radiative history, from the early blackbody stage through neutron migration and collisional heating to internal shocks and neutron decay, culminating in the external blast wave. Recent work by the present researcher shows that the main component of GRB emission is naturally produced at the photosphere of the relativistic jet heated by nuclear and Coulomb collisions. The current study will use three state-of-the-art numerical codes that calculate radiative transfer, collisional processes, and collective plasma processes in the expanding jet. The ultimate goal is to reconstruct the radiative history of GRB jets and estimate their Lorentz factors and magnetization.

GRB research impacts various fields in astronomy, from the theory of stellar core-collapse to jets in active galactic nuclei to early star formation in the Universe to future gravitational wave astronomy to new theories of mass extinction on the Earth. GRB research also impacts fundamental physics through understanding new properties of matter under extreme conditions. The research will involve graduate and undergraduate students, and the results will be disseminated at conferences and taught as part of high-energy astrophysics courses at Columbia University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cosmological gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) are emitted by powerful jets from compact central engines, and the project focused on detailed numerical simulations of radiative processes in the jet. A new technique was developed to model the produced radiation. Comparison of the simulations with observations showed that (1) most of the observed radiation comes from the jet photosphere, (2) the opaque region behind the photopshere is strongly heated by internal dissipative processes, (3) typically a few per cent of the jet energy is stored in the magnetic field, and (4) neutrino emission from the heated GRB jet can be observed with the IceCube/DeepCore detector in the moderate energy range of 10-100 GeV. These findings open a new method for estimating the main parameters of GRB jets, including their speed, power, and magnetization.

Detailed numerical simulations were also used to study the puzzling flashes of GeV gamma-rays detected by the Fermi satellite from GRBs. The study led to a new model for the GeV flash, which implies the creation of copious electron-positron pairs around GRB explosions. The results provided evidence for a dense medium around the GRB trigger, with density decreasing with distance from the center. The medium was found to be consistent with a wind from a massive stellar progenitor whose collapse triggered the explosion. The developed model also predicted an accompanying optical flash. The prediction was confirmed by observations of a nearby GRB in April 2013. Understanding the mechanism of the double (GeV plus optical) flash opens new prospects for the analysis of the GRB phenomenon, reconstruction of the explosion history and its progenitor.
